questions.text: A 40-year-old lady presented with a midline thyroid swelling which has been gradually increasing in size for the last 3 years. On examination, a hard, solitary nodule with irregular borders was palpable. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy was performed and showed multiple layers of well-differentiated cuboidal epithelium covering the papillae and optically clear appearing cells without nuclei. Which gene mutation is not involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition described here is papillary thyroid carcinoma, and it is not associated with mutations of the TP53 gene. Mutations involving the inactivation of TP53 are restricted to anaplastic carcinomas and contribute to their aggressive behavior.

The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • The carcinoma shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with simple or stratified cuboidal epithelium.
  • On high power, the nuclei appear optically clear or empty as the chromatin is dispersed. These empty appearing nuclei are called Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Concentric calcified structures called psammoma bodies are usually seen.
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion by the tumour are usually present.

Chromosomal rearrangements in papillary thyroid carcinoma include:

  • Mutations involving RET proto-oncogene: Results in RET fusion proteins RET/PTC which are involved in 40% of papillary thyroid carcinomas. The frequency of RET/PTC rearrangements is significantly higher in cases with a history of radiation exposure.
  • Mutations involving NTRK1: These genetic events also produce constitutively active NTRK1 fusion proteins. They are present in 5% to 10% of papillary thyroid cancers.
  • BRAF: One-third to half of the papillary thyroid carcinomas involve a gain-of-function mutation in the BRAF gene. The presence of BRAF mutations in papillary carcinomas correlates with poorer prognostic factors like metastasis extrathyroidal extension.

questions.text: A 6-year-old, otherwise healthy girl developed fever and a mild respiratory illness. A week later, a diffuse erythematous rash appeared on her face, as shown in the image below. The rash progressed to involve the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. Which is the true statement about the management of this condition?

choices.text: Children with rash and arthropathy should be excluded from school till symptoms subside
Infected children with transient red cell aplasia should be given specific antiviral therapy
Infected children with transient red cell aplasia should be isolated during treatment
IVIG should be given as post exposure prophylaxis to infected children

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with fever, mild respiratory illness, and rash as described point to a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease) caused by parvovirus B19, and infected children with red cell aplasia should be isolated during the treatment. The image shows the classical slapped cheek appearance.

Children with B19-induced RBC aplasia have a higher viral load and are infectious on presentation. They usually require transfusions and supportive care. They should be isolated in the hospital during their treatment to prevent spread to susceptible patients and staff. Isolation should be continued for at least 1 week and after resolution of fever.

Erythema infectiosum presents as a prodrome of low-grade fever, headache, and a mild upper respiratory tract infection after an incubation period of 4-28 days. A characteristic rash occurs in 3 stages:

  • Erythematous facial flushing causing a slapped cheek appearance in the 1st stage
  • Diffuse macular erythema spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities in the 2nd stage.
  • Central clearing of the macular lesions, giving the rash a lacy, reticulated appearance in the 3rd stage.

The rash is more prominent on extensor surfaces and spares the palms and soles. At this stage, affected children are afebrile and do not appear ill.  Children with erythema infectiosum are not likely to be infectious at presentation. Isolation and exclusion from school are unnecessary and ineffective after diagnosis as the rash and arthropathy are immune-mediated, postinfectious phenomena.

Complications of the disease include:

  • Arthralgias or arthritis
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis: A transient arrest of erythropoiesis and absolute reticulocytopenia in serum hemoglobin in individuals with chronic hemolytic conditions like sickle cell anemia
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Myocarditis
  • A papular-purpuric “gloves-and-socks” syndrome 
  • Neurological: Aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, and peripheral neuropathy, stroke in children with sickle cell disease 
  • Infection-associated hemophagocytic syndrome in immunocompromised patients
  • Maternal infection is associated with nonimmune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise

There is no data to support the use of IVIG for postexposure prophylaxis, however, it has been used with some success to treat B19-related episodes of anemia and bone marrow failure in immunocompromised children. There is no specific antiviral therapy for B19 infection.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with halitosis and regurgitation of food for the past 7 months. He mentions that he often feels like food is stuck in his throat. A barium swallow was performed and the findings are shown below. Which of the following procedures is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow are suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. The procedure used for the treatment of this condition is Dohlman's procedure.

The pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum is a protrusion of the mucosa through Killian's dehiscence a weak area of the posterior pharyngeal wall between the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus and the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus.

It presents at around 60 years of age and is more common in men than women. The patients usually experience regurgitation of foul-smelling, undigested food, halitosis and recurrent cough. The diagnosis is usually made by a lateral barium swallow.

The treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The endoscopic treatment of Zenker's diverticulum is also called the Dohlman technique. It is a transoral endoscopic approach in which the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Other options:

Option A: Heller myotomy is used for the treatment of achalasia cardia.

Option C: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is used to treat infantile pyloric stenosis.

Option D: Nissen's fundoplication is used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and hiatal hernia.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the orthopedic OPD with an injury to her wrist after falling on an outstretched hand 2 days ago. She complains of pain in the radial aspect of her wrist. On examination, there is fullness and tenderness in the anatomic snuffbox. An X-ray was taken but it appeared to be normal.  In addition to the standard X-ray views used, which among the following can be used for further assessment of the suspected fracture?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with fullness and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox following a fall on outstretched hand is a case of scaphoid fracture, and the Ziter view is used for further assessment.

Ziter view, also called banana view is a posteroanterior view of the wrist in ulnar deviation with 20-degree tube angulation to the elbow. The X-ray beam will be at right angles to the long axis of the bone. It aids in the identification of scaphoid waist fractures. However, fractures that are oblique to the x-ray beam are not well identified.

Four standard views used for assessment of scaphoid fractures are:

  • Neutral posteroanterior (PA) view 
  • Neutral lateral view 
  • 45-degree radial oblique view (semi supinated) - detects proximal pole fractures, humpback deformities, and avulsion fractures
  • 45-degree ulnar oblique view (semipronated) - Detects oblique sulcal, displaced waist fractures, and tubercle fractures

Neutral PA and lateral views can determine carpal alignment and perilunate fracture-dislocations, but they are poor at fracture detection, especially with the tubercle overhang found on the neutral PA view.

Soft tissue signs of a scaphoid fracture on plain X-rays include the scaphoid fat pad sign (obliteration or lateral displacement of the normal scaphoid fat pad) and the pronator fat pad/stripe sign (prominent fat pad of pronator quadrates over the volar aspect of the wrist)

If the initial X-rays appear normal, treat the clinical diagnosis and immobilize the wrist in a cast. Repeat X-rays may be needed after 2 weeks (and sometimes even later) before the fracture line shows.

 

Other options:

Option A: Kelly view or Canale view is used to evaluate the talar neck, anterior calcaneal process, and calcaneocuboid joint in ankle injuries.

Option C: Broden view is used to evaluate the posterior subtalar joint in ankle injuries

Option D: Ball catcher view, also known as Nørgaard projection, or posterior oblique view of both hands, is used to assess for erosive arthropathies like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman undergoing surgery was intubated after administering rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. Before anesthesia induction, a mechanosensor was incorporated with electrodes, as shown in the image below. The contraction of which muscle does it assess to monitor neuromuscular activity?
questions.solution:
The mechanosensor with electrodes is placed over the region of the ulnar nerve, thus assessing the contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle to monitor neuromuscular activity.

Monitoring of neuromuscular blockade is required to monitor the blockade intraoperatively, ensure its complete reversal postoperatively, and prevent residual blockade. To monitor the neuromuscular function, a peripheral motor nerve is supramaximally stimulated and the response of the muscle is assessed.

The most commonly assessed nerve-muscle unit is the ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle. This is because it is easily accessible, has the lowest risk of direct muscle stimulation, and the response can be evaluated tactilely, visually, or by objective methods. To stimulate the ulnar nerve, the electrodes are best applied to the volar aspect of the wrist.

Other nerve-muscle units that can be assessed include:

  • Posterior tibial nerve-flexor hallucis brevis muscle
  • Facial nerve-orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Facial nerve-corrugator supercilii muscle

Many methods can be used for objective monitoring of neuromuscular function:

  • Mechanomyography (MMG)
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Acceleration of the muscle response (AMG)
  • Kinemyography (KMG)
  • Cuff pressure modality (CPM)
  • Compressomyography (CMG)
  • Phonomyography (PMG)

The image shows AMG, which is based on Newton’s second law: force = mass × acceleration. It measures the isotonic acceleration of the stimulated muscle.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old female child, who appeared normal at birth was brought to the OPD when the parents noticed dryness of the skin with scaly lesions on the child’s body. They mention that skin lesions improve when the weather is more humid. On examination, you notice scaling as shown in the image below, present on the extensor surfaces of the body, sparing the groin and large flexures. Identify the true statement(s) about the condition.
  1. It is an autosomal recessive condition
  2. Immunohistochemical studies show an absence or marked reduction in filaggrin signal
  3. It is caused by mutations in the STS gene
  4. Patients show accentuated palmar creases
  5. Glycerol containing creams are beneficial
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image point to a diagnosis of ichthyosis vulgaris and statements 2, 4, and 5 are true about this condition.

Ichthyosis Vulgaris is a mild scaling disorder characterized by the presence of excessive amounts of dry thickened scaly skin. It is due to filaggrin mutations (FLG), which are inherited as an autosomal semi-dominant trait and immunohistological studies show an absent or markedly reduced filaggrin signal.

Ichthyosis Vulgaris is not present at birth but develops during the first months of life. Patients present with light grey fish-like scales mainly on the extensor surfaces and the trunk, sparing the groin and larger flexural surfaces. The palmar and plantar creases are frequently accentuated in this condition.

Patients benefit from ointments that hydrate the stratum corneum. Creams containing glycerol, urea, or lactic acid work well in this condition. 

Other options: A recessive X‐linked ichthyosis (RXLI) is caused by mutations in the STS gene leading to deficiency of steroid sulfatase. It usually presents before 3 months of age with large thick dark brown to yellow‐brown hyperkeratoses covering the trunk, the extremities, and the neck. Flexural surfaces, palms, and soles are spared.

questions.text: A patient experienced chest tightness, and breathlessness after going on a pilgrimage site which was at an altitude of 3574 m above sea level. He had ascended to that height in one day. During the initial period of acclimatization period, which of the following changes is most likely to occur?

choices.text: Shift of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right

questions.solution:
During the initial process of acclimatization to high altitudes, respiratory alkalosis occurs as a result of hyperventilation. 

The symptoms of chest tightness and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness, which can be prevented by gradual ascent with sufficient time for acclimatization.

Following are the physiological changes that occur during acclimatization:

  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation (hyperventilation). This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis. The initial state of alkalosis shifts the oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left, which in later stages of acclimatization shifts to right due to increased 2,3 - DPG.
  • Increased erythropoietin secretion, leading to an increase in circulating red blood cells
  • Increased number of mitochondria
  • Increased myoglobin to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues
  • Increased tissue cytochrome oxidase
  • Increased sympathetic tone
  • Renal suppression of carbonic anhydrase and excretion of dilute alkaline urine brings the pH of the blood to normal
  • Decreased maximal exercise capacity (by ~1% for every 100 m gained above 1500 m) 

On the ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue, and the following symptoms are seen:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Treatment involves the administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude, and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient presented with fever, productive cough, and night sweats of 3 weeks duration. A history of contact with a TB patient is present. CBNAAT confirms the diagnosis on the sputum sample. Drug susceptibility shows Rifampicin resistance. Bedaquiline based regimen is started as per recent NTEP guidelines. Given below are five statements with regards to Bedaquiline. Which among the given statements is/are false about the drug?
  1. It is a bacteriostatic drug that inhibits Mycobacterium 5' ATP synthase enzyme.
  2. It is always advisable to take Bedaquiline with a high-fat diet. 
  3. Bedaquiline has a high volume of distribution and a great CNS penetrating effect.
  4. FDA has issued a black box warning as it prolongs the QTc interval.
  5. 20% of people having clofazimine resistance can show resistance to Bedaquiline.
questions.solution:
The incorrect statements is 1 and 3. Bedaquiline is bactericidal and has a poor CNS penetration. 

Bedaquiline:

Bedaquiline is one of the recent drugs approved for the treatment of MDR/ XDR TB.

  • It is a bactericidal agent and acts by inhibiting the proton pump activity of the Mycobacterial 5' ATP synthase enzyme.
  • It has a great volume of distribution and is lipid-soluble. High-fat food increases its absorption.
  • It has very poor CNS penetration.
  • It is principally metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme system and is eliminated by the fecal route.
  • The most common side effect of the drug is GI disturbance (nausea) while the most fatal, for which a black-box warning was issued by US-FDA is QTc prolongation and should be used with caution with people having cardiac conduction anomalies. It is hepatotoxic and may cause hyperuricemia.
  • Resistance to this drug is mediated by a two-point mutation of D32V and A63P genes. Cross-resistance is seen with Clofazimine due to mutation of the efflux pump MmpL. 

Recent Update:

Pretomanid is a new drug approved by the FDA in August 2019.

It is recommended in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid (the BPaL regimen) for the treatment of adults with pulmonary extensively drug resistant (XDR), treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB).

Delamanid is a new drug that can be used in MDR-TB patients. However, it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text:
A multiparous non-lactating obese lady seeks contraception advice. She has deranged blood glucose levels from her last pregnancy. She had an ectopic pregnancy 3 years back. Which oral contraceptive pill is best suited for her?

GDM - Gestational Diabetes Mellitus
questions.solution:
The oral contraceptive pill best suited for this patient is a triphasic combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). It has no adverse effect on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism and has a good safety profile in diabetic women. 

Triphasic combined oral contraceptive pills are those with estrogen and progesterone dosages varying in three different phases of the same cycle. 

These are preparations of Ethinyl estradiol (EE2) and levonorgestrel (LNG) given as 3 phases in a menstrual cycle with different dosages- 

  • First 6 days- 30mcg EE2 + 50mcg LNG
  • Next 5 days- 40mcg EE2 + 75mcg LNG
  • For the next 10 days- 30mcg EE2 + 125mcg LNG 
  • Followed by a 1-week drug-free interval 

These triphasic OCPs can be safely used in those at risk of myocardial infarction. These are as effective as monophasic pills but are not used in cases with menorrhagia.

During contraceptive use, if one dose is missed, that day’s pill plus the missed pill should be taken as soon as remembered and the remaining pack is then completed as usual. If several doses are missed, then two pills are taken with an additional effective barrier technique for the next 7 days or a new pack can be started with an additional barrier method.

Other options:

Progesterone-only pills /mini-pills can be given for diabetes, but the failure rate is higher in obese women. There is a high risk of ectopic pregnancy (up to 10% of pregnancies reported in clinical studies) in progestin-only oral contraceptive users. Since this woman already has a history of ectopic, this may not be a preferable method. 

Monophasic pills comprise a constant dose of progestin and estrogen throughout the cycle. It causes derangement of lipid and carbohydrate metabolism and thus is contraindicated in diabetes mellitus. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with immune thrombocytopenic purpura is undergoing elective splenectomy. During the procedure, injury to which of the following ligaments can lead to a complication of pancreatitis?

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presented with right hip pain. On examination, his BMI is 29 and there is a shortening of the limb with limitation of abduction, flexion, and internal rotation. Which among the following lines is drawn on the X-ray for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition described is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) and the line used to diagnose it is Klein’s line - marked in green.

Klein's line is a line drawn on the A-P view or frog lateral view of the hip X-ray along the superior border of the neck of the femur. Failure of Klein’s line to intersect with the epiphysis results in a positive Trethowan sign- seen in SCFE. Klein’s line is less sensitive for diagnosis in the pre-slip stage.

A modification of this measurement is that if the maximal width of the epiphysis lateral to Klein's line is 2 mm or more than that in the contralateral hip, it is considered as a slip.

 

Other X-ray features seen in SCFE include :

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee. On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated. There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side. Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign. Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other options:

The other three lines are used in the diagnosis of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).

Hilgenreiner's line (Red line in the image) - A horizontal line through the tri-radiate cartilages.

Perkin's line (Blue line in the image) - A vertical line drawn at the outer border of the acetabulum. It is perpendicular to Hilgenreiner's line.

In DDH, the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrant formed by these two lines.

Shenton's line (Yellow line in the image) - A smooth curve formed by the inferior border of the neck of the femur with the superior margin of the obturator foramen. It is broken in DDH.

questions.text:
Given below are five statements regarding the process of glycogen synthesis and glycogenolysis. Which of the following statements are not correct?
  1. Phosphoglucomutase is a common enzyme to both glycogen synthesis and glycogenolysis. 
  2. In liver, epinephrine promotes cAMP dependant glycogen breakdown.
  3. The activities of the enzymes Glycogen synthase and glycogen phosphorylase are reciprocally regulated.
  4. Nor-epinephrine inhibits the breakdown of glycogen.
  5. Glycogenolysis is generally increased in low insulin - glucagon ratio states.
questions.solution:
The incorrect statements are 2 and 4 only. In liver, epinephrine promotes cAMP-independent glycogenolysis and Nor-epinephrine promotes the breakdown of glycogen. 

cAMP-independent glycogenolysis is also activated by nor-epinephrine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and angiotensin II.

Other statements:

Statement 1: Phosphoglucomutase is involved in both glycogenesis & glycogenolysis. 

Statements 3: The activities of the enzymes glycogen synthase and glycogen phosphorylase are reciprocally regulated. Both phosphorylase and glycogen synthase exists in both phosphorylated and nonphosphorylated states, and the effect of phosphorylation seen in glycogen synthase is the reverse of that seen in glycogen phosphorylase. Phosphorylation activates glycogen phosphorylase whereas inactivates glycogen synthase.

Statement 5: Low-insulin/glucagon ratio indicates low insulin and high glucagon levels, which are observed in the fasting state. Glucagon mediates phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase and glycogen synthase. Phosphorylation activates phosphorylase and deactivates synthase. Hence glycogenolysis is increased in fasting states. Glycogen synthesis occurs in the liver and skeletal muscle, in the fed state, under the effect of insulin.

questions.text: A young man met with a bike accident. He lost all his motor, sensory, and autonomic functions of the spinal cord below the level of the lesion. However, vibration and position sensations are preserved. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis of the patient is Anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome. 

ASA infarct typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion. Since the dorsal column is located in the posterior or dorsal aspect of the spinal cord, it is spared.

Other options:

Central cord syndrome:

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and crossing spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. In the cervical cord, the central cord syndrome produces arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness and a “dissociated” sensory loss, meaning loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution), in contrast to the preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in these regions.

Foramen magnum syndrome:

Around the clock pattern of weakness is described and manifests as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. The pattern of the weakness may begin in any of the limbs. 

Brown–Sequard Syndrome: ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract) and loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column), with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract) one or two levels below the lesion

questions.text:
A third-year medical student was asked the draw the Ohngren’s line. The line drawn by him is as shown in the below image(dotted line) where "A" and "B"  represents maxillary tumour growth
below and above the Ohngren’s line. Which of the following option is true regarding the prognosis of maxillary tumour?

choices.text: Both A and B has poor prognosis
Both A and B has Good prognosis
A has Poor prognosis and B has Good prognosis
A has Good prognosis and B has Poor prognosis

questions.solution:
"A" has Good prognosis and "B" has Poor prognosis is the true statement.

Ohngren’s line is an imaginary line passing through medial canthus of eye and angle of mandible.

It is used for classification of maxillary carcinoma.

  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

questions.text: A study was conducted in which 10,000 women participated in the cervical smear tests. 1,500 had positive smears, of which 1000 later tested positive with the gold standard biopsy test. 50 women who had a negative smear also tested positive on biopsy. What is the best term that can describe these 50 women cases?
questions.solution:
The women who tested positive on biopsy(the gold standard), but identified as negative by the cervical smear (screening test) are False-negatives, i.e. they are sick identified wrongly as healthy.

The number of cases identified correctly as sick - True positive

Healthy cases identified as healthy - True negative 

Healthy cases identified as sick - False positive

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: A male patient came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft. Pruritus is absent. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of brittle beard hair with the presence of soft, white nodules loosely adherent along the hair shaft is suggestive of white piedra and the causative agent is Trichosporon beigelii.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types: white piedra and black piedra. 

White piedra is caused by Trichosporon beigelii. It is characterized by the presence of soft, white, or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic and facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is seen in the culture as nodules in the form of a sheath extending around the hair shaft. Arthroconidia and blastoconidia are seen.

Black piedra is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. It is caused by Piedraia hortae (option C). On microscopy, they appear as brown, thick-walled with septate hyphae and chlamydoconidia.

Shaving or cutting off the affected hair is useful in managing both black and white piedra. In black piedra, topical benzoic acid and terbinafine is helpful while topical antifungals, azoles, and allylamines can be useful in white piedra.

Other superficial mycoses and infectious organisms are Hortaea (Exophiala) werneckii (option B) causing tinea nigra. They cause lesions in the palm which appear dark brown to black in color. On Sabouraud agar, they appear as grey or black colonies. Skin scrapings reveal brownish branched septate hyphae and budding cells.

Tinea versicolor (Option D) or Pityriasis versicolor is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species like Malassezia globosa, Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur. The characteristic lesions are macules that are hypo or hyperpigmented on the chest, upper back, arms, or abdomen. Skin scrapings show yeast-like cells and short branching filaments.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman working in a night-shift call center presents with complaints of generalized weakness and fatigue for the past 3 months that has progressively become worse. She says it gets worse towards the morning, and she feels better in the evenings after a period of rest. She has unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the right eye. Following evaluation, she is started on tablet edrophonium for the treatment of her condition.  Which of the following autoantibody is not associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) but not with myasthenia gravis.

The patient experiences generalized weakness, which progresses and becomes worse after exertion. The presence of unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the right eye along with generalized weakness is suggestive of a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents–Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine.
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment.
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy

Preferred drug for diagnosis: Edrophonium

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: Which of the following condition commonly has an appearance of watered silk on fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
On fundus examination, the Hypermetropic eye has a bright reflex suggesting the appearance of watered silk.

Signs of hypermetropia include the following:

  • Size of the eyeball: small.
  • The cornea may be slightly smaller.
  • Short anteroposterior length of the eyeball.
  • Fundus picture:
    • Pseudopapillitis - characterized by a small optic disc, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins and without disc edema
    • Watered silk appearance - The retina, as a whole, may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections.

The convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a violent attack. The patient has injuries over her forearm and elbow. On examination, she has injuries over her breasts and inner thighs. Pelvic examination reveals lacerations in the vaginal mucosa. On enquiring about the injuries, the patient is unable to remember the violent incident. Which of the following defense mechanism best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and examination are suggestive of rape, and the patient is repressing the memory of the incident as a means of coping with the anxiety.

Repression is a type of psychological defense mechanism that involves keeping certain thoughts, feelings, or urges out of conscious awareness. The goal of this form of defense is to keep unacceptable desires or thoughts out of the conscious mind in order to prevent or minimize feelings of anxiety.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Which among the following is the active principle present in the dried fruit shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are semicarpol and bhilawanol.

Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew.

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

Other options

Option A: Calotropin is one of the active principles of Calotropis.

Option C: Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius

Option D:  Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis.
